Now humans do. The friend of the past was someone with whom you shared secrets and meals. It's now a verb for connecting with someone on social media.
Those are just two of the words whose definitions have changed drastically over the past decades thanks to technology, social media and the ways we communicate. To celebrate its 20th birthday, Dictionary.com released a list of 20 words that mean something different than they did in 1995.
Click through the slides above to review those words, then share others that have changed in the past 20 years in the comments.
Most of the words are connected to technology, which enables their definitions to quickly spread far and wide, according to Dictionary.com. Facebook and Twitter introduced the new like, timeline, friend and tweet, while smartphones brought along the new swipe.
"We are proud to celebrate 20 years of helping people all over the world unlock the power of language and apply it to their daily lives, from conversations with friends to a post on Facebook," Liz McMillan, chief executive officer of Dictionary.com, said in a statement. "This list shows just how much the rise of technology has shaped our word use over time, and is a fun way to revisit the evolution of the English language since the dawn of the Internet era."
